title: Re-analysis of the Food Safety Plan
description: Requirements for periodic re-analysis of the Food Safety Plan including triennial review schedule, change management triggers, and documentation of re-analysis activities

requirements.text: Is there documented evidence that there is a re-analysis of the Food Safety Plan at least once every 3 years and when significant changes are made?
requirements.question: Is there documented evidence that there is a re-analysis of the Food Safety Plan at least once every 3 years and when significant changes are made?
mandatoryStatements: The complete Food Safety Plan must be reanalyzed at least once every three years to ensure continued adequacy and effectiveness
Reanalysis must be conducted whenever significant changes occur including new products, process modifications, new hazards, or regulatory changes
Reanalysis must be performed by or overseen by the PCQI with comprehensive evaluation of all plan elements and documentation of findings
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will examine reanalysis documentation to verify comprehensive Food Safety Plan reviews are conducted at least every three years. Records must show reanalysis dates, PCQI involvement, scope of review, findings, and any modifications made to the plan. The auditor will verify reanalysis occurred following significant changes such as new product introductions, process modifications, equipment changes, facility expansions, new scientific information about hazards, changes in intended use or consumer populations, or new regulations. Reanalysis documentation should demonstrate systematic evaluation of hazard analysis, preventive controls, monitoring procedures, corrective actions, verification activities, and record-keeping. The auditor will verify reanalysis was conducted by or under oversight of a PCQI with signatures confirming their involvement. Any plan modifications resulting from reanalysis should be documented with implementation dates and training records for affected personnel.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Management must establish a schedule tracking triennial reanalysis due dates to ensure reviews are completed on time without lapses exceeding three years. The PCQI must lead or oversee all reanalysis activities with documented involvement. Reanalysis must be comprehensive covering all Food Safety Plan elements: hazard analysis for all products, preventive control adequacy, critical limits and parameters, monitoring procedures and frequencies, corrective action procedures, verification activities, supply chain program, recall plan, and record-keeping systems. When significant changes occur, change management procedures must trigger reanalysis requirements before changes are implemented. The PCQI must evaluate whether changes introduce new hazards, affect existing preventive controls, or require plan modifications. Reanalysis findings must be documented in detail showing what was reviewed, issues identified, decisions made, and plan modifications required. When plan modifications are made, affected documentation must be updated, personnel retrained as needed, and changes verified for effectiveness. Reanalysis provides an opportunity for continuous improvement by incorporating lessons learned, new technologies, improved procedures, and enhanced controls. Management must ensure adequate resources and time are allocated for thorough reanalysis.

capaInject: Implement immediate corrective actions when triennial re-analysis deadlines are missed requiring accelerated review and documentation
Establish procedures for triggering Food Safety Plan re-analysis when significant process, equipment, or ingredient changes occur
Develop action plans when re-analysis identifies new hazards or inadequate existing controls requiring preventive control modifications
Create preventive measures including change management systems to ensure all significant changes prompt timely Food Safety Plan re-analysis
Implement verification procedures confirming PCQI conducts comprehensive re-analysis addressing all elements of the Food Safety Plan
traceabilityInject: Maintain re-analysis schedule documentation showing triennial review dates, responsible PCQI, and completion status tracking
Keep change management records documenting significant changes that trigger Food Safety Plan re-analysis requirements
Retain re-analysis reports showing comprehensive review of hazard analysis, preventive controls, monitoring, and verification procedures
Document modifications made to Food Safety Plan following re-analysis including rationale, PCQI approval, and implementation dates
Archive continuous improvement records showing how re-analysis findings drive enhanced food safety controls and system effectiveness
micro_inject: Failure to conduct triennial re-analysis allows outdated preventive controls that no longer address current Listeria monocytogenes contamination patterns
Missing re-analysis after significant changes permits introduction of new cross-contamination pathways for Salmonella from modified equipment
Inadequate re-analysis fails to recognize emerging pathogen threats including antibiotic-resistant bacteria requiring enhanced control measures
Delayed re-analysis after ingredient changes misses new hazards such as Clostridium botulinum risk in reformulated low-acid products
Lack of systematic change management results in preventive controls that fail to control E. coli O157:H7 introduced through new raw material sources
